meta_data.title: A Very Gracious Acceptance Speech From Mordecai and Esther
meta_data.subtitle: ESTHER 9:20-29 Thanks to everyone who supports TMBH at  You're the reason we can all do this together!  Opening song, "" from the album, "" by

transcription_data.text: Recently, somebody had knew one in a ward. That was a cool award. The award was basically a Your Awesome award. I was there for the award being given. I got to hear the whole speech and everything. It's kind of wild that the one person who was omitted in this individual's acceptance speech was himself. He thanked literally everybody else and deferred credit for everything and said things that really mostly were about expressing gratitude and about encouragement and exhortation to anybody who was hearing the speech. He was very, very well done. I was super impressed and I was super proud of my friend. And likewise, here in the second half of Esther chapter 9, we're getting the same kind of treatment from Mordecai and Esther. This summary, this roundup is all being written from the perspective of Mordecai and Esther, or maybe second hand from the perspective of Mordecai and Esther via what could be interpreted, what could be gleaned from these two letters that they apparently sent out to Jews all around the Aquamanid, the Persian Empire. And all of these letters in the authority of it was all coming from the right hand man of the king. Remember Mordecai took Haman's place. So he's not just some guy trying to get people excited, like, come on guys, a celebrated thing. Let's band together, let's believe in our hearts and let's make this a new deal. Come on guys. Nah, I didn't like that at all. This is a highly authoritative position, but on top of that, this is somebody who just, I mean, he's getting credited or who a lot of people would look at and say, that dude and the queen just saved all of us from being dead. So rarely has there ever been such an opportunity for somebody to be riding such a high in terms of popular support and influence to cash it in and get what they want. And I think it's pretty compelling that what we find that Esther and Mordecai really want as we get into the home stretch here is they wanted the Jews not to be killed and they want people to remember what happened and to have peace and unity among them, even as they celebrate on different days because of how the timing all worked out. And I mean, really, what more do they need? They already won Haman's estate, which was big enough to offer a quarter of a billion dollars in modern money terms to the king early on in the book of Esther. That's been bequeat to Esther who immediately was like, I'm the queen of the king in the empire. It's the best empire they ever had in the history of all the empires. And I, bro, I'm fine. I'm just going to give it to Mordecai if that's cool in the king. I mean, he's not really the type to object to much of anything. So Mordecai takes over Haman's massive estate. Esther's just fine. So when you already have everything, well, what else could you possibly want? Well, I mean, the stuff I just said, right? It's not hard to read between the lines and figure out that's what they really wanted to see happen. That being peace among the Jewish people around the empire who were going to celebrate this a little differently and all different calendar. It's weird. Doesn't seem like that would be a big thing. But that is the kind of thing that people can get worked up about and have fights about. So clearly, Esther and Mordecai in their victory lap, if you will, after all of this worked out, they're writing a couple of letters. And one of those letters is, hey, let's, let's not get after each other about celebrating on the wrong day. Here's why everybody celebrates when they do. It's because there was a second day of chaos and working this thing out. That's how it was very euphemistic of me. Mordecai recorded these events and he sent letters to all the Jews throughout the provinces of King Xerxes near and far to have them celebrate annually. The 14th and 15th days of the month of Adar as of the time when the Jews got relief from their enemies and as the month when their sorrows were turned into joy and they're morning into a day of celebration. He wrote them to observe the days as days of feasting and joy and giving presents of food to one another and gifts to the poor. Side note that is, I mean, it's brutal. It's super mean of whoever wrote this to have the word poor and poor happening again and again in the same passage, especially while I'm sick. I'm doing my best. So the Jews agreed to continue the celebration. They had begun doing what Mordecai had written to them. And now this will be looked at yesterday. For Haman, son of Hamadatha, the Agagite, the enemy of all the Jews had plotted against the Jews to destroy them and cast to the poor. That is the lot for their ruin and destruction. But when the plot came to the king's attention, he issued written orders that the evil scheme Haman had devised against the Jews should come back on to his own head and that he and his sons should be hanged on the gallows. Therefore, these days were called pooram from the word poor. And I think we've already covered that and established that, but you know, there it is. You cast the poor, pooram. I don't it seems like it makes perfect sense. Great name for the holiday. Because of everything written in this letter and because of what they had seen and what had happened to them, the Jews took it upon themselves to establish the custom that they and their descendants and all who joined them should without fail observe these two days every year in the way prescribed and at the time appointed. These days should be remembered and observed in every generation by every family and in every province and in every city and to these days of pooram should never cease to be celebrated by the Jews nor should the memory of them die out among their descendants. So Queen Esther, daughter of Abba Heilel, along with Mordecai the Jew, wrote with full authority to confirm this second letter concerning pooram. So there you go. You got two letters that they kick out there and none of it seems to have anything to do with how awesome Mordecai and Esther are. It doesn't sound like it has anything to do with them getting stuff. It doesn't really sound like they take any credit for anything whatsoever. Ultimately, it looks like they're totally content to let the unseen hand of providence receive credit for how this works out. And I think that does demonstrate growth and change regarding their characters. And even if I'm reading into that too much, any reader of this book could agree that they end up in a place of humility and concern for others and concern that this lesson, I believe about the providence of God and how He will sustain His people as well as the lesson of the importance of remembrance, that seems to be the thing that they really want to pass down through the generations and that they really want people to remember. So just like my buddy who won a big award and decided not to use his time on the stage to take any kind of credit for himself whatsoever, it looks like Mordecai and Esther choose the same approach and instead make their whole victory lap about the well-being of other people. I think that's pretty cool. Hey, last thing. You and I are busting our butts on this. We're putting a lot of work and effort and thought into making deep dives into the Bible a part of our daily rhythm. And every time we get done with one of these books, with one of these seasons, I got to feeling like we need something to commemorate that to market that's available to everybody, whether you support the program or not. And you never, I mean, it's just it ain't where you do not have to support this thing. I am so glad everybody is here and grateful to those who are able to kick him. And there's no expectation ever at all. But everybody who is here, we need something to market. And so I hired my friend, Bethany, who's done all the branding for everything that I do here. My buddy Destin, she's done the branding for him on Smarter Every Day. And our podcast, No Dumb Questions, and Ironwood Rhino, which I ran for a little while. And this is just everything. She's the artist behind that. She's so good. And she listens to this program as well. She knows the material. And so I commissioned her to make these beautiful little works of art in the form of sort of achievement unlocked stickers. Esther is done and ready to go. And it's beautiful thematically. It communicates so much about what this book is and what we're taking from it. And I think it's a cool milestone, a cool achievement marker that all of us physically, tangibly can have that isn't going to absolutely annihilate the bank for me and that I can just send automatically to everybody who supports the show in any way. And then I can make available to anybody who at any point works their way through the book of Esther and wants to just go buy the sticker to be a part of their achievement unlocked, got this book in my hip pocket collection. I'm thinking about putting the stickers for me after we get done with the book in the little cardstock area in the first couple of pages of my Bible or maybe on the first page, the description page in my Bible. I don't know. It's going to go somewhere cool. They're not huge. They're maybe two inches by three inches. They look like a little book with the name of the book on the spine and then 10 minute Bible hour on the bottom and then the cool artwork in the middle. I'm going to make one that has a white outline and that's the one that anybody can buy from the website. I'll get that set up soon so you can pick that up and add it to your collection. When you've got this book in your hip pocket and you finish the season with me and then there's going to be one that has a gold outline that I mail to literally anybody who is supporting the program on any platform at any level in any way at the time that I actually mail the sticker, which in this case is going to go out with the Nehemiah Field Guide or Field Notes books when I get my hands on those. And then finally, there's a small handful of people who have gone ludicrously way above and beyond and I am going to do a super special mega limited edition. Nobody else can get it. Hologram sticker for you. And I mean, there's not like some kind of hard number on that or anything. There's just a few of you and I think you know who you are and I wanted to do something, anything to acknowledge that and tip my hat and say thank you to you for that. Ultimately, all of you make this go, whether you support the program or not, it wouldn't happen if you weren't interested in thinking about this in normal language with a normal person together and cutting each other slack and showing each other grace and just thinking it through together honestly even understanding that we might land in different places with what we do with it at any given time. It is a journey of working through wildly important influential stuff together and I think it's a big deal and I think the stickers will be a cool way even if not the hugest thing ever to just commemorate that because it matters. And every one of these books that we do together is a huge step in terms of the journey of faith and life and growth and belief. But also it's a moment in your history and you only get so many of those and I think it's cool. And even if you don't think of life that way, I do. So I thought the sticker thing would be really cool. Again, the Esther stickers will be available for sale with the white outline sometime soon on the website and the gold outline ones will just send those out to everybody who's supporting here. As soon as I get the shipment in on those Nehemiah field notes books, they'll go out together. All right, y'all are awesome. I appreciate you so much. Thanks again for laboring with me as I'm under the weather and my voice is even more grading than usual. Y'all are patient. And I'm Matt. This is a 10 minute Bible hour podcast. Let's do this again. See you next time.
